Summary:

The patient is a 64-year-old male admitted to the ICU with altered mental status (AMS) and acute hypoxemic respiratory failure. He has a history of atrial fibrillation and is currently on diltiazem. The patient has had a PICC line inserted and is receiving antibiotics. He has been experiencing low-grade fevers, and blood and urine cultures have been sent. The patient's neurological status is deteriorating, and he is non-responsive except to painful stimuli.

Potential medical complications:

1. Meningitis: The patient's altered mental status and low-grade fevers may be indicative of meningitis. The lumbar puncture was negative for meningitis, but the patient's condition may still be worsening due to an underlying infection.
2. Pyelonephritis: The patient's CTA showed right lower lobe pneumonia, and the urine culture is pending. Pyelonephritis is a possible complication of the patient's underlying infection.
3. Respiratory failure: The patient's oxygen saturation is 96% on nasal cannula, but his respiratory status may be worsening due to his underlying condition.
4. Sepsis: The patient's fever, tachycardia, and altered mental status may indicate sepsis, which could lead to organ failure if not addressed promptly.
5. Bleeding: The patient's low hemoglobin and hematocrit levels may indicate bleeding, which could be due to the patient's underlying condition or the insertion of the PICC line.
6. Cardiovascular instability: The patient's atrial fibrillation and hypertension may indicate cardiovascular instability, which could lead to cardiac arrest if not managed properly.
7. Infection: The patient's altered mental status and low-grade fevers may indicate an underlying infection, which could spread to other parts of the body if not treated promptly.
8. Neurological deterioration: The patient's neurological status is deteriorating, which could be due to an underlying condition or a complication of the patient's treatment.

These potential complications highlight the need for close monitoring and aggressive management of the patient's underlying condition, as well as the need for further testing and treatment to determine the underlying cause of the patient's symptoms.

   Assessment and Plan
   82 y/o F w/ multiple myeloma, frequent recent falls in setting of
   severe peripheral neuropathy who now p/w acute on chronic subdural
   hematoma and pneumonia after an unwitnessed fall.  Transferred back to
   MICU after becoming non responsive, febrile and in afib with [**Year (4 digits) 1978**].
   .
   # AMS - unclear etiology, CT of head negative for change in SDH and
   patient moving all 4 extremities.  Would continue to monitor CTs for
   changes as needed.  Neuro consult, checking dilantin levels and EEG.
   Could be secondary to infection as patient is febrile.  Has known
   pneumonia.  [**Month (only) 8**] be c.diff in the setting of broad spectrum abx.  Maybe
   meningitis, although LP initially negative.  Could be drug effect,
   although not on any sedating meds now except oxybutinin.  Is
   hemodynamically stable and should have adequate perfusion to brain.
   Recent MRI showed nonobstruction flow.
   - f/u pan cultures of blood, urine, stool
   - f/u LP cultures
   - EEG today to rule out subclinical seizures
   - MRI to rule out stroke
   - LENIs and CTA neg for clots
   - hold oxybutinin
   - follow up neuro recs
   - could be delirium in setting of pain
   .
   # Fever - fever today, culturing, is immunecompromised secondary to
   pulse steroids for MM.  Being treated for HAP and aspiration pneumonia
   with broad spectrum vanco, cefepime, flagyl.  Not covering ESBLs.  Also
   not covering fungal infections.
   - f/u cultures
   - continue current abx
 see if infection declares itself
   - consider DVT as source of fever, f/u LENIs
   - hemodynamically stable, does not appear septic
   .
   # RUQ pain - unclear etiology, patient is post cholecystectomy so not
   gallbladder pain.  Could be rib fracture v. pleural pain v. colitis vs.
   pneumonia pain.
   - f/u abdominal ultrasound
 negative
   - CT abd and pelvis did not show pathology which could account for
   pain; consider possible obstructing stone as cause as it would not be
   well visualized on CT
   - no abx for now
   .
   # Subdural Hematoma: Neurosurgery following, no acute change from OSH
   imaging, no changes in CT today.
   - transfuse plt's with goal of >80, plt 96 now
   - INR 1.5, s/p Vit K treatment
   - continue dilantin at an appropriately corrected level; holding lyrica
   is in setting of no POs
   .
   # Afib with [**Name (NI) 1978**] - unclear precipitating factor, likley in setting of
   fever and new infection.  BPs stable, HRs to 140s.  Not changed with
   metoprolol; IV dilt pushes work.
   - start dilt gtt, transition to PO if GI access achieved
   - echo done earlier in admission, no need to repeat at this time
   - no PE based on CTA
   - EKG without signs of ischemia
   .
   # Respiratory/PNA: Has known PNA on CXR, treated from the start.  Abx
   treatment included vanco and cefepime started [**3-29**].  Did get one dose
   of ceftriaxone.  Was started on levo for atypical coverage on [**3-29**]
   which was stopped [**4-2**].  Flagyl was started [**4-2**] (today).  Culture data
   only positive for GPCs in sputum, no speciation done.  Is tachypneic
   but oxygentating well.
   - cont vancomycin, cefepime for 7 days (until [**4-5**])
   - oxygen to maintain sats >92%
   - CXR and CTA without changes, still with RLL PNA
   .
   # Falls/?Syncope: recent admit with extensive work-up attributing LE
   weakness and falls to cervical spondylosis and multilevel degenerative
   disease with myelopathy and neuropathy. Unclear if LOC with fall.
   - tele
   - MRA of neck done on last admit showing no flow limiting lesions
   - dilantin as above for seizure ppx
   - monitor resp status
   .
   # Myeloma: On pulse decadron as per heme-onc for tx of myeloma.
   - Next pulse due in 1 week.
   - will touch base with heme onc about next steroid dose
   .
   # Pancytopenia: [**3-7**] to myeloma.
   - Transfuse platelets with goal > 80K
   - Transfuse hct < 21
   .
   # Renal Failure: At baseline from last admission. Unclear etiology to
   CKD, but may represent complication from myeloma.
   - Trend Cr
   - Cr 1.2 up from 1.1 yesterday (high was 1.3 this admission)
   .
   # FEN: NPO for AMS, replete lytes PRN
   .
   # Prophylaxis: pneumoboots (no SQ hep d/t SDH), PPI, pneumovax given at
   OSH
   .
   # Access: PICC line
   .
   # Code: Ok to intubate, patient declines resuscitation but son who is
   HCP says yes to intubation.
   .
   # Communication: Patient, son is HCP, family meeting today
   .
   # Disposition: pending resp status improvement, PT c/s
   ICU Care

   Assessment and Plan
   82 y/o F w/ multiple myeloma, frequent recent falls in setting of
   severe peripheral neuropathy who now p/w acute on chronic subdural
   hematoma and pneumonia after an unwitnessed fall.  Transferred back to
   MICU after becoming non responsive, febrile and in afib with [**Year (4 digits) 1978**].
   .
   # AMS - unclear etiology, CT of head negative for change in SDH and
   patient moving all 4 extremities.  Would continue to monitor CTs for
   changes as needed.  Neuro consult, checking dilantin levels and EEG.
   Could be secondary to infection as patient is febrile.  Has known
   pneumonia.  [**Month (only) 8**] be c.diff in the setting of broad spectrum abx.  Maybe
   meningitis, although LP initially negative.  Could be drug effect,
   although not on any sedating meds now except oxybutinin.  Is
   hemodynamically stable and should have adequate perfusion to brain.
   Recent MRI showed nonobstruction flow.
   - f/u pan cultures of blood, urine, stool
   - f/u LP cultures
   - EEG today to rule out subclinical seizures
   - MRI to rule out stroke
   - LENIs and CTA neg for clots
   - hold oxybutinin
   - follow up neuro recs
   - could be delirium in setting of pain
   .
   # Fever - fever today, culturing, is immunecompromised secondary to
   pulse steroids for MM.  Being treated for HAP and aspiration pneumonia
   with broad spectrum vanco, cefepime, flagyl.  Not covering ESBLs.  Also
   not covering fungal infections.
   - f/u cultures
   - continue current abx
 see if infection declares itself
   - consider DVT as source of fever, f/u LENIs
   - hemodynamically stable, does not appear septic
   .
   # RUQ pain - unclear etiology, patient is post cholecystectomy so not
   gallbladder pain.  Could be rib fracture v. pleural pain v. colitis vs.
   pneumonia pain.
   - f/u abdominal ultrasound
 negative
   - CT abd and pelvis did not show pathology which could account for
   pain; consider possible obstructing stone as cause as it would not be
   well visualized on CT
   - no abx for now
   .
   # Subdural Hematoma: Neurosurgery following, no acute change from OSH
   imaging, no changes in CT today.
   - transfuse plt's with goal of >80, plt 96 now
   - INR 1.5, s/p Vit K treatment
   - continue dilantin at an appropriately corrected level; holding lyrica
   is in setting of no POs
   .
   # Afib with [**Name (NI) 1978**] - unclear precipitating factor, likley in setting of
   fever and new infection.  BPs stable, HRs to 140s.  Not changed with
   metoprolol; IV dilt pushes work.
   - start dilt gtt, transition to PO if GI access achieved
   - echo done earlier in admission, no need to repeat at this time
   - no PE based on CTA
   - EKG without signs of ischemia
   .
   # Respiratory/PNA: Has known PNA on CXR, treated from the start.  Abx
   treatment included vanco and cefepime started [**3-29**].  Did get one dose
   of ceftriaxone.  Was started on levo for atypical coverage on [**3-29**]
   which was stopped [**4-2**].  Flagyl was started [**4-2**] (today).  Culture data
   only positive for GPCs in sputum, no speciation done.  Is tachypneic
   but oxygentating well.
   - cont vancomycin, cefepime for 7 days (until [**4-5**])
   - oxygen to maintain sats >92%
   - CXR and CTA without changes, still with RLL PNA
   .
   # Falls/?Syncope: recent admit with extensive work-up attributing LE
   weakness and falls to cervical spondylosis and multilevel degenerative
   disease with myelopathy and neuropathy. Unclear if LOC with fall.
   - tele
   - MRA of neck done on last admit showing no flow limiting lesions
   - dilantin as above for seizure ppx
   - monitor resp status
   .
   # Myeloma: On pulse decadron as per heme-onc for tx of myeloma.
   - Next pulse due in 1 week.
   - will touch base with heme onc about next steroid dose
   .
   # Pancytopenia: [**3-7**] to myeloma.
   - Transfuse platelets with goal > 80K
   - Transfuse hct < 21
   .
   # Renal Failure: At baseline from last admission. Unclear etiology to
   CKD, but may represent complication from myeloma.
   - Trend Cr
   - Cr 1.2 up from 1.1 yesterday (high was 1.3 this admission)
   .
   # FEN: NPO for AMS, replete lytes PRN
   .
   # Prophylaxis: pneumoboots (no SQ hep d/t SDH), PPI, pneumovax given at
   OSH
   .
   # Access: PICC line
   .
   # Code: Ok to intubate, patient declines resuscitation but son who is
   HCP says yes to intubation.
   .
   # Communication: Patient, son is HCP, family meeting today
   .
   # Disposition: pending resp status improvement, PT c/s
   ICU Care
   Nutrition:

Based on the progress note, the patient is an 82-year-old female with a history of multiple myeloma, frequent recent falls, and severe peripheral neuropathy who was admitted to the ICU with acute on chronic subdural hematoma and pneumonia.

The patient's vital signs are:

* Temperature: 38.3°C (100.9°F)
* Heart rate: 106 bpm
* Blood pressure: 120/61 mmHg
* Respiratory rate: 24 breaths per minute
* Oxygen saturation: 96%
* Heart rhythm: Atrial fibrillation

The patient's physical examination reveals:

* General appearance: Not well nourished, no acute distress, thin
* Eyes: PERRL (pupils equal and reactive to light)
* Head, Ears, Nose, Throat: Normocephalic, black left eye
* Cardiovascular: Normal PMI, normal S1 and S2 heart sounds
* Respiratory: Symmetric chest expansion, no clear breath sounds, crackles, or bronchial sounds
* Abdominal: Soft, non-tender, bowel sounds present, tender RUQ
* Extremities: Right and left radial pulses present, but absent DP pulses
* Skin: Warm
* Neurologic: Responds to noxious stimuli, oriented to nothing, non-purposeful movement, tone not assessed

The patient's laboratory results show:

* White blood cell count: 8.4 K/uL
* Hemoglobin: 6.6 g/dL
* Platelet count: 76 K/uL
* Creatinine: 1.3 mg/dL
* Troponin-T: 0.04 ng/mL
* Glucose: 143 mg/dL
* Lactic acid: 1.0 mmol/L
* LDH: 454 IU/L
* Calcium: 8.3 mg/dL
* Magnesium: 1.5 mg/dL
* Phosphorus: 3.9 mg/dL

The patient's medical conditions include:

* Acute on chronic subdural hematoma
* Pneumonia
* Myeloma
* Pancytopenia
* Renal failure
* Atrial fibrillation
* Fever
* RUQ pain

The patient's potential medical complications include:

* Meningitis
* Sepsis
* Pneumonia
* Aspiration pneumonia
* DVT
* Pulmonary embolism
* Stroke
* Delirium
* Subclinical seizures
* C. difficile infection
* Fungal infection

The patient's plan of care includes:

* Monitoring of vital signs and laboratory results
* Administration of antibiotics for pneumonia and aspiration pneumonia
* Treatment of fever with antipyretics and antibiotics
* Management of RUQ pain with analgesics and anti-inflammatory medications
* Monitoring of platelet count and transfusion as necessary
* Monitoring of renal function and treatment of renal failure as necessary
* Monitoring of atrial fibrillation and treatment as necessary
* Monitoring of neurological status and treatment of subdural hematoma as necessary
* Family meeting to discuss code status and advance directives.

   MICU after becoming non responsive, febrile and in afib with [**Year (4 digits) 1978**].
   .
   # AMS - unclear etiology, CT of head negative for change in SDH and
   patient moving all 4 extremities.  Would continue to monitor CTs for
   changes as needed.  Could be secondary to infection as patient is
   febrile.  Has known pneumonia.  [**Month (only) 8**] be c.diff in the setting of broad
   spectrum abx.  Could be drug effect, although not on any sedating meds
   now except oxybutinin.  Is hemodynamically stable and should have
   adequate perfusion to brain.  Recent MRI showed nonobstruction flow.
   - f/u pan cultures of blood, urine, stool
   - hold oxybutinin
   - follow up neuro recs
   .
   # Fever - fever today, culturing, is immunecompromised secondary to
   pulse steroids for MM.  Being treated for HAP and aspiration pneumonia
   with broad spectrum vanco, cefepime, flagyl.  Not covering ESBLs.  Also
   not covering fungal infections.
   - f/u cultures
   - continue current abx
   - consider DVT as source of fever, f/u LENIs
   - hemodynamically stable, does not appear septic
   .
   # RUQ pain - unclear etiology, patient is post cholecystectomy so not
   gallbladder pain.  Could be rib fracture v. pleural pain v. colitis.
   - f/u abdominal ultrasound
   - consider abx
   .
   # Subdural Hematoma: Neurosurgery following, no acute change from OSH
   imaging, no changes in CT today.
   - q4H neuro checks overnight
   - transfuse plt's with goal of >80, plt 96 now
   - INR 1.3, s/p Vit K treatment
   - continue dilantin; was also on pregabalin but floor team was consider
   stopping it - will follow up with neuro recs
   .
   # Afib with [**Name (NI) 1978**] - unclear precipitating factor, likley in setting of
   fever and new infection.  BPs stable, HRs to 140s.  Not changed with
   metoprolol; IV dilt pushes work.
   - start dilt gtt
   - echo in AM, TSH (of note had echo initially in hospitalization as
   part of syncope workup which was unrevealing except for pulm HTN)
   - consider CTA to r/o PE as cause of new afib
   - EKG without signs of ischemia
   - trend CEs to rule out ischemia, although unlikely cause
   .
   # Respiratory/PNA: Has known PNA on CXR, treated from the start.  Abx
   treatment included vanco and cefepime started [**3-29**].  Did get one dose
   of ceftriaxone.  Was started on levo for atypical coverage on [**3-29**]
   which was stopped [**4-2**].  Flagyl was started [**4-2**] (today).  Culture data
   only positive for GPCs in sputum, no speciation done.  Is tachypneic
   but oxygentating well.
   - cont vancomycin, cefepime for 7 days (until [**4-5**])
   - oxygen to maintain sats >92%
   - CXR to look for new, changing infiltrates; pleural effusions or other
   lung changes.
   .
   # Falls/?Syncope: recent admit with extensive work-up attributing LE
   weakness and falls to cervical spondylosis and multilevel degenerative
   disease with myelopathy and neuropathy. Unclear if LOC with fall.
   - tele
   - MRA of neck done on last admit showing no flow limiting lesions
   - dilantin as above for seizure ppx
   - monitor resp status
   .
   # Myeloma: On pulse decadron as per heme-onc for tx of myeloma.
   - Next pulse due in 1 week.
   - d/w outpatient heme-onc
   .
   # Pancytopenia: [**3-7**] to myeloma.
   - Transfuse platelets with goal > 80K
   - Transfuse hct < 21
   .
   # Renal Failure: At baseline from last admission. Unclear etiology to
   CKD, but may represent complication from myeloma.
   - Trend Cr
   - Cr 1.2 up from 1.1 yesterday (high was 1.3 this admission)
   .
   # FEN: NPO for AMS, replete lytes PRN
   .
   # Prophylaxis: pneumoboots (no SQ hep d/t SDH), PPI, pneumovax given at
   OSH
   .
   # Access: PICC line
   .
   # Code: Ok to intubate, patient declines resuscitation but son who is
   HCP says yes to intubation.
   .
   # Communication: Patient, son is HCP
   .
   # Disposition: pending resp status improvement, PT c/s
   ICU Care

Summary:

The patient is an 82-year-old female with multiple myeloma, who was admitted with acute on chronic subdural hematoma and pneumonia after an unwitnessed fall. She has been experiencing fever, altered mental status, and is currently non-responsive. The patient has a history of severe peripheral neuropathy and is immunocompromised due to pulse steroids for myeloma treatment.

The patient's condition is complex and multifaceted. The potential medical complications that can arise include:

1. Meningitis: The patient's altered mental status and fever could be indicative of meningitis, which is a serious and potentially life-threatening condition.
2. Sepsis: The patient's fever and altered mental status could be indicative of sepsis, which is a life-threatening condition that requires prompt recognition and treatment.
3. Pulmonary embolism: The patient's tachypnea and oxygen requirement could be indicative of a pulmonary embolism, which is a serious and potentially life-threatening condition.
4. Pneumonia: The patient's known pneumonia and recent antibiotics may not have fully cleared the infection, which could lead to further complications.
5. Subdural hematoma: The patient's subdural hematoma may worsen and require surgical intervention.
6. Renal failure: The patient's baseline renal failure may worsen, which could lead to further complications.
7. Pancytopenia: The patient's pancytopenia may worsen, which could lead to further complications.
8. Infection: The patient's immunocompromised state and recent antibiotics may make her more susceptible to infection.
9. DVT: The patient's tachypnea and oxygen requirement could be indicative of a DVT, which is a serious and potentially life-threatening condition.
10. Respiratory failure: The patient's tachypnea and oxygen requirement could lead to respiratory failure, which is a life-threatening condition.

The patient's medical history and current condition require close monitoring and management to prevent and address these potential complications.

The patient is a 64-year-old individual admitted to the ICU with a chief complaint of altered mental status (AMS). The patient has a history of atrial fibrillation, and the ECG shows AF. The patient has a low hemoglobin level of 19%, and a CTA showed no pulmonary embolism, but a right lower lobe pneumonia (RLL PNA) was detected. The patient has a PICC line in place, and blood cultures were sent. The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 38.3°C, heart rate of 106 bpm, and blood pressure of 120/61 mmHg.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Sepsis: The patient's low hemoglobin level and high temperature (38.3°C) suggest the possibility of sepsis, which can lead to organ dysfunction and failure.
2. Pneumonia: The CTA showed a right lower lobe pneumonia (RLL PNA), which can lead to respiratory failure and complications.
3. Anemia: The patient's low hemoglobin level of 19% can lead to anemia, which can cause fatigue, weakness, and shortness of breath.
4. Bleeding: The patient's low platelet count and low hemoglobin level suggest the possibility of bleeding, which can lead to hemorrhage and organ failure.
5. Cardiac Complications: The patient's atrial fibrillation and low blood pressure can lead to cardiac complications, such as cardiac arrest or heart failure.
6. Neurological Complications: The patient's altered mental status (AMS) can lead to neurological complications, such as seizures, coma, or brain death.
7. Infection: The patient's low white blood cell count and high temperature suggest the possibility of infection, which can lead to sepsis and organ failure.
8. Renal Complications: The patient's low blood pressure and high creatinine level suggest the possibility of renal complications, such as acute kidney injury or chronic kidney disease.

These potential medical complications highlight the importance of close monitoring and management of the patient's condition in the ICU.

Based on the patient's progress note, the patient is an 82-year-old woman admitted to the MICU with subdural hematoma (SDH) after a fall, as well as pneumonia (PNA) and a chest X-ray (CXR) showing infiltrate and floor on [**9-27**]. She was initially on the floor with poor mental status (MS), right upper quadrant (RUQ) pain, fever, and atrial fibrillation (AFib) with rapid ventricular response (RVR). She was started on a diltiazem drip, which helped to control her heart rate.

The patient's 24-hour events include the placement of a PICC line, EKG, ultrasound, lumbar puncture (LP), blood culture, and urine culture. Her lab results show normal white blood cell count, but elevated lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) and troponin-T. Her blood cultures are pending.

The patient's assessment and plan include:

1. Poor mental status: Unclear cause, no evidence of meningitis. Consider delirium versus subclinical seizures. Will get EEG and follow-up LP results.
2. Fever: Unclear source, could be from hematoma although this is a diagnosis of exclusion on therapy for PNA with vancomycin and cefepime.
3. RUQ pain: Exam seems benign currently, no clear pathology on US or CT. U/A was negative, making pyelonephritis unlikely.
4. AFib: Underlying pulmonary hypertension and likely diastolic dysfunction. Unclear precipitant. Tolerating diltiazem drip, unable to take PO currently. Will try to get Dobhoff placed.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

1. Seizures: Given the patient's history of SDH and the presence of subclinical seizures, there is a risk of seizure activity.
2. Infection: The patient's fever and positive blood cultures could indicate a bacterial infection, which could lead to sepsis and organ failure.
3. Cardiac complications: The patient's AFib with RVR and underlying pulmonary hypertension could lead to cardiac complications such as cardiogenic shock or arrhythmias.
4. Renal failure: The patient's elevated LDH and troponin-T could indicate renal damage, which could lead to acute kidney injury or chronic kidney disease.
5. Respiratory failure: The patient's pneumonia and underlying chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) could lead to respiratory failure.
6. Gastrointestinal bleeding: The patient's use of anticoagulation therapy and the presence of SDH could increase the risk of gastrointestinal bleeding.
7. Delirium: The patient's poor MS and underlying medical conditions could lead to delirium, which could increase the risk of falls, aspiration, and other complications.

Overall, the patient is critically ill and requires close monitoring and management to prevent complications and improve her clinical status.

   - continue current abx
 see if infection declares itself

   - hemodynamically stable, does not appear septic

 negative

Based on the provided progress note, I summarize the patient's condition as follows:

The patient is an 82-year-old female with a history of multiple myeloma, frequent recent falls, and severe peripheral neuropathy. She has been admitted to the ICU with acute on chronic subdural hematoma, pneumonia, and febrile response. The patient is non-responsive, febrile, and in atrial fibrillation with a recent CT scan showing no acute changes.

The patient has undergone extensive work-up, including imaging studies, laboratory tests, and infectious disease consultations. The differential diagnosis includes:

1. Delirium: The patient's non-responsive state and fever could be attributed to delirium caused by pain, infection, or medication.
2. Meningitis: Although the LP was initially negative, the patient's febrile response and known pneumonia raise the possibility of meningitis.
3. Infection: The patient's febrile response and known pneumonia may be secondary to infection, which could be caused by bacteria, fungi, or viruses.
4. Seizure disorder: The patient's non-responsive state and recent fall may be attributed to a seizure disorder, which could be caused by medication, infection, or underlying neurological condition.
5. Drug effect: The patient's non-responsive state could be attributed to the effects of medication, including sedatives or anticholinergics.

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's tachypnea and known pneumonia may lead to respiratory failure.
2. Sepsis: The patient's febrile response and known pneumonia may lead to sepsis.
3. Stroke: The patient's known subdural hematoma and atrial fibrillation may increase the risk of stroke.
4. Pneumonia progression: The patient's known pneumonia may progress, leading to worsening respiratory function.
5. Renal failure: The patient's known chronic kidney disease and recent increase in creatinine levels may worsen, leading to renal failure.

The patient's plan of care includes:

1. Monitoring of vital signs and neurological status.
2. Continued antibiotic treatment for pneumonia.
3. Culturing of blood, urine, and stool to identify potential infections.
4. EEG and MRI to rule out seizure disorder and stroke.
5. Transfusion of platelets and consideration of transfusion of packed red blood cells.
6. Monitoring of renal function and consideration of dialysis if necessary.
7. Family meeting to discuss code status and disposition.

The patient's code status is DNR (do not resuscitate), and her disposition is pending improvement in respiratory status.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 64-inch tall individual with a complex medical history, currently admitted to the ICU. The patient's 24-hour events include a preliminary EEG showing diffuse encephalopathy, a stable hematoma on MRI, and chronic microvascular infarct with no acute changes. The patient has been transitioned from dilantin IV to oral dilantin, and attempts to place a feeding tube have been unsuccessful due to the patient's inability to cooperate. The patient has a history of anemia, abdominal pain, fever, altered mental status, and atrial fibrillation.

Physically, the patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature range of 37.6°C to 38.3°C, heart rate between 94 and 121 beats per minute, and blood pressure between 116/66 and 158/82 mmHg. The patient's respiratory support includes nasal cannula oxygen delivery, with an SpO2 of 97%. The patient's neurological examination is incomplete due to the patient's inability to cooperate.

Laboratory results show anemia, with a hemoglobin level of 7.7 g/dL, and elevated white blood cell count, with a count of 10.7 K/uL. The patient's liver enzymes are elevated, with ALT at 51 and AST at 71. The patient's electrolyte levels are within normal range, with the exception of a slightly elevated potassium level of 4.7 mEq/L.

The patient's assessment and plan include anemia secondary to blood loss, abdominal pain, fever, altered mental status, and atrial fibrillation. The patient's ICU care includes nutrition, glycemic control, and prophylaxis for deep vein thrombosis, stress ulcers, and ventilator-associated pneumonia.

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

1. Sepsis: The patient's fever and elevated white blood cell count may indicate the presence of an infection, which could lead to sepsis.
2. Bleeding: The patient's anemia and elevated international normalized ratio (INR) may increase the risk of bleeding.
3. Respiratory failure: The patient's atrial fibrillation and respiratory support with nasal cannula oxygen may increase the risk of respiratory failure.
4. Neurological deterioration: The patient's altered mental status and incomplete neurological examination may indicate the presence of a neurological disorder or injury, which could lead to further deterioration.
5. Liver dysfunction: The patient's elevated liver enzymes may indicate liver dysfunction, which could lead to further complications.
6. Electrolyte imbalance: The patient's slightly elevated potassium level may indicate an electrolyte imbalance, which could lead to cardiac arrhythmias or muscle weakness.

It is essential to closely monitor the patient's condition and adjust their treatment plan accordingly to prevent or manage these potential complications.

Summary:

The patient is an 82-year-old female with a history of multiple myeloma, frequent recent falls, and severe peripheral neuropathy. She was admitted to the ICU after becoming non-responsive, febrile, and in atrial fibrillation (AFib) following an unwitnessed fall. The patient has a subdural hematoma, pneumonia, and is receiving broad-spectrum antibiotics for suspected HAP and aspiration pneumonia. She has a history of pancytopenia due to myeloma and is receiving pulse steroids for treatment.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Infection: The patient is at high risk for infection due to her immunocompromised state, broad-spectrum antibiotics, and presence of pneumonia. The patient's fever and positive cultures from blood, urine, and stool suggest a possible infection.
2. Cerebral Edema: The patient's subdural hematoma and chronic microvascular infarct may lead to cerebral edema, which could worsen her neurological status.
3. Respiratory Failure: The patient's pneumonia and tachypnea put her at risk for respiratory failure, which could require intubation and mechanical ventilation.
4. Cardiac Complications: The patient's AFib and history of myeloma increase her risk for cardiac complications, such as arrhythmias, heart failure, and cardiogenic shock.
5. Renal Failure: The patient's pre-existing chronic kidney disease (CKD) and potential nephrotoxicity from antibiotics may worsen her renal function, leading to acute kidney injury.
6. Gastrointestinal Complications: The patient's history of falls and possible gastrointestinal bleeding put her at risk for gastrointestinal complications, such as perforation or hemorrhage.
7. Neurological Complications: The patient's subdural hematoma, chronic microvascular infarct, and potential cerebral edema may lead to neurological complications, such as seizures, stroke, or cognitive decline.
8. Venous Thromboembolism (VTE): The patient's immobility and history of falls increase her risk for VTE, which could lead to pulmonary embolism or deep vein thrombosis.

Assessment and Plan:

The patient's condition is complex and requires close monitoring and management. The patient's fever, pneumonia, and possible infection require ongoing antibiotic therapy and cultures. The patient's subdural hematoma and chronic microvascular infarct require ongoing neurological monitoring and potential neurosurgical intervention. The patient's respiratory status requires close monitoring, and intubation may be necessary if respiratory failure develops. The patient's cardiac status requires close monitoring, and potential cardioversion may be necessary if AFib persists. The patient's renal function requires close monitoring, and potential nephrotoxicity from antibiotics may require dose adjustments. The patient's gastrointestinal status requires close monitoring, and potential gastrointestinal bleeding may require endoscopy or surgery. The patient's neurological status requires close monitoring, and potential seizures or stroke may require anticonvulsant therapy or thrombolytic therapy.

Based on the patient's progress note, the following summary and potential medical complications can be identified:

Summary:

The patient is a 64-inch tall individual with a history of anemia, abdominal pain, fever, altered mental status, and atrial fibrillation. The patient has been admitted to the ICU for further management. The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 38.3°C, heart rate of 94 beats per minute, and blood pressure of 116/66 mmHg. The patient's respiratory status is stable, with an SpO2 of 97% on nasal cannula oxygen. The patient's neurologic status is altered, with non-purposeful movement and no orientation to self or environment.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Infection: The patient's fever and altered mental status may indicate an underlying infection, which could lead to sepsis, organ dysfunction, and mortality.
2. Hemodynamic instability: The patient's atrial fibrillation and altered mental status may lead to hemodynamic instability, which could result in cardiac arrest, respiratory failure, and other complications.
3. Gastrointestinal bleeding: The patient's abdominal pain and anemia may indicate gastrointestinal bleeding, which could lead to hypovolemic shock, acidosis, and other complications.
4. Respiratory failure: The patient's altered mental status and atrial fibrillation may lead to respiratory failure, which could result in hypoxia, hypercapnia, and other complications.
5. Seizures: The patient's altered mental status and diffuse encephalopathy on EEG may indicate a risk of seizures, which could lead to further neurological damage and mortality.
6. DVT and VTE: The patient's immobility and altered mental status may increase the risk of DVT and VTE, which could lead to pulmonary embolism, deep vein thrombosis, and other complications.
7. Sepsis-induced kidney injury: The patient's altered mental status and infection may lead to sepsis-induced kidney injury, which could result in acute kidney injury, chronic kidney disease, and other complications.
8. Hypoglycemia: The patient's altered mental status and glycemic control may indicate a risk of hypoglycemia, which could lead to seizures, coma, and other complications.

These potential medical complications highlight the need for close monitoring and aggressive management to prevent and treat any complications that may arise.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is an 82-year-old female with a history of multiple myeloma, frequent recent falls, and severe peripheral neuropathy. She was admitted with acute on chronic subdural hematoma and pneumonia after an unwitnessed fall.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Neurological: The patient is non-responsive, febrile, and in atrial fibrillation. She has a diffuse encephalopathy on EEG and a chronic microvascular infarct on MRI. She is not able to cooperate with feeding tube placement.
* Respiratory: The patient has known pneumonia and is being treated with broad-spectrum antibiotics. She is tachypneic but oxygenating well.
* Cardiovascular: The patient has atrial fibrillation, which is likely related to the fever and new infection. Her blood pressure is stable, and her heart rate is in the 140s.
* Hemodynamic: The patient is hemodynamically stable, with a normal blood pressure and a heart rate that is responsive to metoprolol.
* Renal: The patient has chronic kidney disease at baseline, and her creatinine level is 1.2 mg/dL.
* Blood: The patient has pancytopenia, with a platelet count of 76,000/mm³, a white blood cell count of 8.4, and a hemoglobin level of 7.7 g/dL.
* Liver: The patient has an elevated lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) level of 454 IU/L, which may indicate liver dysfunction.
* Infection: The patient has a fever, and cultures are pending. She is being treated with broad-spectrum antibiotics, but the coverage is not optimal.
* Neurosurgical: The patient has a subdural hematoma, which is being monitored with serial CT scans.

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's current condition include:

* Seizures: The patient's diffuse encephalopathy and chronic microvascular infarct may increase her risk of seizures.
* Infection: The patient's fever and positive cultures may indicate a bacterial infection, which could lead to sepsis or organ failure.
* Respiratory failure: The patient's tachypnea and known pneumonia may increase her risk of respiratory failure.
* Cardiac arrhythmias: The patient's atrial fibrillation may increase her risk of cardiac arrhythmias, such as ventricular tachycardia or fibrillation.
* Renal failure: The patient's chronic kidney disease and elevated creatinine level may increase her risk of acute kidney injury or worsening of her chronic kidney disease.
* Bleeding: The patient's pancytopenia and platelet count may increase her risk of bleeding complications.
* Liver dysfunction: The patient's elevated LDH level may indicate liver dysfunction, which could lead to coagulopathy or other complications.

The patient's code status is DNR (do not resuscitate), and her disposition is pending improvement in her respiratory status.

Summary:

The patient is a 65-year-old male admitted to the ICU for respiratory failure due to community-acquired pneumonia. Over the past 24 hours, the patient's condition has remained stable, with no significant changes in vital signs, hemodynamic monitoring, or respiratory support. The patient's physical examination remains unchanged, with bilateral wheezing and decreased lung sounds. Laboratory results show a slight increase in white blood cell count and a decrease in hemoglobin level. The patient's blood glucose level remains elevated, and imaging studies show no new abnormalities.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's condition is precarious, and there is a high risk of further deterioration in respiratory function, leading to the need for mechanical ventilation or even extracorporeal membrane oxygenation (ECMO).
2. Sepsis: The patient's pneumonia may lead to sepsis, which can cause organ dysfunction, including cardiovascular instability, renal failure, and hepatic dysfunction.
3. Pneumonia progression: The patient's pneumonia may progress, leading to further lung damage, consolidation, and potentially life-threatening complications such as acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS).
4. Gastrointestinal bleeding: The patient's stress ulcer prophylaxis may not be sufficient, leading to gastrointestinal bleeding, which can exacerbate respiratory failure and increase the risk of bleeding complications.
5. Venous thromboembolism (VTE): The patient is at high risk of developing VTE due to immobility, and prophylactic measures should be continued to prevent this complication.
6. Insulin resistance: The patient's elevated blood glucose level may indicate insulin resistance, which can worsen respiratory failure and increase the risk of complications.
7. Infection control: The patient is at risk of developing ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP), which can be prevented by maintaining proper respiratory hygiene and avoiding unnecessary antibiotics.

Recommendations:

1. Continue close monitoring of the patient's respiratory status, with frequent assessment of oxygenation and ventilation.
2. Administer antibiotics as prescribed, and consider adjusting the regimen if the patient's condition does not improve.
3. Maintain stress ulcer prophylaxis and monitor for signs of gastrointestinal bleeding.
4. Continue VTE prophylaxis and monitor for signs of deep vein thrombosis.
5. Consider insulin therapy to manage the patient's elevated blood glucose level.
6. Implement infection control measures to prevent VAP, including proper respiratory hygiene and avoiding unnecessary antibiotics.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 37.6°C (99.6°F), heart rate of 102 beats per minute (bpm), and blood pressure of 140/81 mmHg. The patient's respiratory support includes nasal cannula oxygen delivery, with an SpO2 of 95%. The patient's laboratory results show anemia, elevated troponin-T, and abnormal liver function tests.

The patient's medical history includes atrial fibrillation, and the patient is on a DNR (do not resuscitate) code status.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

1. Cardiac arrhythmias: Given the patient's history of atrial fibrillation and the presence of cardiac rhythm control medication, there is a risk of cardiac arrhythmias.

3. Infection: The patient's fever and abnormal liver function tests may indicate an underlying infection, which could worsen if left untreated.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 64-inch tall individual with a history of acute on subacute areas of likely embolic stroke in the right temporal and frontal lobes, as confirmed by MRI. The patient has been admitted to the ICU and is receiving diltiazem infusion at 5 mg/hour, as well as other medications such as vancomycin, cefipime, pantoprazole, and dilantin.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 37.2°C (98.9°F), heart rate of 102 bpm, and blood pressure of 140/81 mmHg. The patient's respiratory rate is 27 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation is 95% on nasal cannula.

The patient's physical examination reveals a non-verbal individual with a normal temperature, blood pressure, and peripheral pulses. The patient's abdomen is soft and non-tender, with bowel sounds present. The patient's neurologic examination shows a non-purposeful movement, and the patient responds to noxious stimuli.

Laboratory results show anemia, elevated white blood cell count, and elevated lactate dehydrogenase (LDH). The patient's blood chemistry is otherwise normal, with the exception of a slightly elevated creatinine level.

The patient's diagnosis includes acute anemia secondary to blood loss, abdominal pain, fever, altered mental status, and atrial fibrillation. The patient's ICU care includes nutrition support with Nutren Pulmonary, glycemic control, and prophylaxis for deep vein thrombosis, stress ulcer, and ventilator-associated pneumonia.

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

1. Increased risk of bleeding due to the patient's anemia and atrial fibrillation.
2. Respiratory complications such as pneumonia or respiratory failure due to the patient's altered mental status and inability to protect their airway.
3. Cardiovascular complications such as heart failure or arrhythmias due to the patient's atrial fibrillation and anemia.
4. Neurological complications such as increased intracranial pressure or seizures due to the patient's acute on subacute areas of likely embolic stroke.
5. Infection due to the patient's fever and altered mental status.
6. Poor wound healing due to the patient's anemia and altered mental status.
7. Increased risk of complications related to the patient's medications, such as bleeding or liver damage.

It is essential to monitor the patient's condition closely and adjust their care plan accordingly to prevent and manage these potential complications.

   Assessment and Plan
   82 y/o F w/ multiple myeloma, frequent recent falls in setting of
   severe peripheral neuropathy who now p/w acute on chronic subdural
   hematoma and pneumonia after an unwitnessed fall.  Transferred back to
   MICU after becoming non responsive, febrile and in afib with [**Year (4 digits) 1978**].
   .
   # AMS - unclear etiology, CT of head negative for change in SDH and
   patient moving all 4 extremities.  Would continue to monitor CTs for
   changes as needed.  Neuro consult, checking dilantin levels and EEG.
   Could be secondary to infection as patient is febrile.  Has known
   pneumonia.  [**Month (only) 8**] be c.diff in the setting of broad spectrum abx.  Less
   likely meningitis, LP initially negative.  Could be drug effect,
   although not on any sedating meds now except oxybutinin.  Is
   hemodynamically stable and should have adequate perfusion to brain.
   Recent MRI showed nonobstruction flow.
   - f/u pan cultures of blood, urine, stool
   - f/u LP cultures
   - EEG
 prelim read is normal
   - MRI to r/o CVA
   - LENIs and CTA neg for clots
   - hold oxybutinin
   - follow up neuro recs
   - could be delirium in setting of pain
   .
   # Fever - fever again today, culturing, is immunocompromised secondary
   to pulse steroids for MM.  Being treated for HAP and aspiration
   pneumonia with broad spectrum vanco, cefepime,.  Not covering ESBLs.
   Also not covering fungal infections.
   - f/u cultures
   - continue current abx
 see if infection declares itself
   - remains hemodynamically stable
   .
   # RUQ pain
 stable, unclear etiology, patient is post cholecystectomy
   so not gallbladder pain.  Could be rib fracture v. pleural pain v.
   colitis vs. pneumonia pain.
   - f/u abdominal ultrasound
 negative
   - CT abd and pelvis did not show pathology which could account for
   pain; consider possible obstructing stone as cause as it would not be
   well visualized on CT
   - no abx for now
   .
   # Subdural Hematoma: Neurosurgery following, no acute change from OSH
   imaging, no changes in CT today.
   - transfuse plt's with goal of >80, plt 96 now
   - INR 1.5, s/p Vit K treatment
   - continue dilantin at an appropriately corrected level; holding lyrica
   is in setting of no POs
   .
   # Afib with [**Name (NI) 1978**] - unclear precipitating factor, likely in setting of
   fever and new infection.  BPs stable, HRs to 140s.  Not changed with
   metoprolol; IV dilt pushes work.
   - transitioned to PO dilt today, as NGT in place
   - echo done earlier in admission, no need to repeat at this time
   - no PE based on CTA
   - EKG without signs of ischemia
   .
   # Respiratory/PNA: Has known PNA on CXR, treated from the start.  Abx
   treatment included vanco and cefepime started [**3-29**].  Did get one dose
   of ceftriaxone.  Was started on levo for atypical coverage on [**3-29**]
   which was stopped [**4-2**].  Flagyl was started [**4-2**]. Culture data only
   positive for GPCs in sputum, no speciation done.  Is tachypneic but
   oxygentating well.
   - cont vancomycin, cefepime for 7 days (until [**4-5**]) , flagyl d/c
   - oxygen to maintain sats >92%
   - CXR stable
   .
   # Falls/?Syncope: recent admit with extensive work-up attributing LE
   weakness and falls to cervical spondylosis and multilevel degenerative
   disease with myelopathy and neuropathy. Unclear if LOC with fall.
   - tele
   - MRA of neck done on last admit showing no flow limiting lesions
   - dilantin as above for seizure ppx
   - monitor resp status
   .
   # Myeloma: On pulse decadron as per heme-onc for tx of myeloma.
   - Next pulse due in 1 week.
   - will touch base with heme onc about next steroid dose
   .
   # Pancytopenia: [**3-7**] to myeloma.
   - Transfuse platelets with goal > 80K
   - Transfuse hct < 21, rcv
d one unit [**2157-4-4**] in AM
   .
   # Renal Failure: At baseline from last admission. Unclear etiology to
   CKD, but may represent complication from myeloma.
   - Trend Cr
   - Cr stable at 1.1
   .
   # FEN: NPO for AMS, replete lytes PRN
   .
   # Prophylaxis: pneumoboots (no SQ hep d/t SDH), PPI, pneumovax given at
   OSH
   .
   # Access: PICC line
   .
   # Code: Ok to intubate, patient declines resuscitation but son who is
   HCP says yes to intubation.
   .

   .

Summary:

The patient is an 82-year-old female with multiple myeloma, who was admitted to the ICU after an unwitnessed fall and was found to have an acute on chronic subdural hematoma and pneumonia. She has a history of severe peripheral neuropathy and has been taking pulse steroids for her myeloma. She is currently receiving broad-spectrum antibiotics for her pneumonia and has been started on anticonvulsant medication for seizure prophylaxis.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 37.6°C, heart rate of 102 bpm, and blood pressure of 140/81 mmHg. She is receiving oxygen therapy and has a SpO2 of 95%. Her respiratory status is stable, with a respiratory rate of 27 breaths per minute.

The patient's laboratory results show a white blood cell count of 8.4 K/uL, hemoglobin of 8.4 g/dL, and platelet count of 76 K/uL. Her renal function is stable, with a creatinine of 1.1 mg/dL. Her liver function tests are slightly elevated, with an aspartate aminotransferase (AST) of 60 IU/L and alanine aminotransferase (ALT) of 94 IU/L.

The patient's medical history is significant for myeloma, which is being treated with pulse steroids. She also has a history of peripheral neuropathy, which may be contributing to her falls.

The patient's plan of care includes continued antibiotic therapy for her pneumonia, anticonvulsant medication for seizure prophylaxis, and close monitoring of her respiratory and renal function.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Sepsis: The patient's pneumonia and recent falls may increase her risk of developing sepsis.
2. Respiratory failure: The patient's pneumonia and tachypnea may increase her risk of developing respiratory failure.
3. Renal failure: The patient's pre-existing kidney disease and recent antibiotic therapy may increase her risk of developing acute kidney injury.
4. Cardiac arrhythmias: The patient's atrial fibrillation and recent falls may increase her risk of developing cardiac arrhythmias.
5. Gastrointestinal bleeding: The patient's anticoagulant therapy and recent falls may increase her risk of developing gastrointestinal bleeding.
6. Neurological complications: The patient's subdural hematoma and recent falls may increase her risk of developing neurological complications, such as seizures or stroke.
7. Infection: The patient's immunocompromised state and recent antibiotic therapy may increase her risk of developing infection.
8. Pneumonia: The patient's pneumonia may worsen and spread to other parts of her lungs.
9. Sepsis syndrome: The patient's pneumonia and recent falls may increase her risk of developing sepsis syndrome.
10. Organ failure: The patient's pre-existing kidney disease and recent antibiotic therapy may increase her risk of developing organ failure.

Based on the physician's daily progress note, the patient is an 82-year-old female with multiple myeloma, who has been admitted to the Intensive Care Unit (ICU) due to an unwitnessed fall, acute on chronic subdural hematoma, and pneumonia.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 37.6°C (99.6°F), heart rate of 102 beats per minute, and blood pressure of 140/81 mmHg. She is on mechanical ventilation and is receiving oxygen therapy.

The patient's laboratory results show a white blood cell count of 8.4 x 10^9/L, hemoglobin of 8.4 g/dL, and platelet count of 76 x 10^9/L. Her electrolyte levels are within normal limits, with a serum creatinine of 1.1 mg/dL and blood urea nitrogen of 26 mg/dL.

The patient's radiology results show acute and subacute infarcts in the right temporal and frontal lobes, with no hemorrhagic conversion. Her MRI shows non-obstruction flow, and her CT scan of the head shows no acute change from the original scan.

The patient's medical history is significant for multiple myeloma, frequent recent falls, and severe peripheral neuropathy. She has also had a recent episode of diarrhea, which is pending testing for Clostridioides difficile (C. diff).

The patient's current medications include diltiazem, pantoprazole, and Dilantin. She is also receiving antibiotics for her pneumonia, including vancomycin and cefepime.

The patient's assessment and plan include:

* AMS: unclear etiology, with a possible contribution from infection, medication, or delirium
* Fever: secondary to immunocompromised state and pneumonia
* RUQ pain: unclear etiology, with possible causes including rib fracture, pleural pain, or colitis
* Subdural hematoma: no acute change from original imaging, with no indication for transfusion
* Afib: unclear precipitating factor, with possible causes including fever and new infection
* Respiratory/PNA: abx treatment includes vancomycin and cefepime, with a possible diagnosis of GPCs in sputum
* Diarrhea: pending testing for C. diff
* Falls/?Syncope: unclear etiology, with possible causes including cervical spondylosis and multilevel degenerative disease
* Myeloma: on pulse decadron for treatment of myeloma
* Pancytopenia: secondary to myeloma
* Renal failure: at baseline from last admission, with unclear etiology
* FEN: NGT TF at goal, with repletion of lytes PRN

The patient's potential medical complications include:

* Seizures: due to AMS, medication, or infection
* Infection: secondary to immunocompromised state and pneumonia
* Pneumonia: with possible complications including respiratory failure and sepsis
* Renal failure: with possible complications including electrolyte imbalance and acidosis
* Gastrointestinal bleeding: due to diarrhea and possible C. diff infection
* Cardiac arrhythmias: due to afib and possible electrolyte imbalance
* Neurological complications: due to subdural hematoma and possible AMS

Overall, the patient's condition is complex and requires close monitoring and management to prevent potential complications.

Summary:

The patient is an 82-year-old female with a history of multiple myeloma, frequent recent falls, and severe peripheral neuropathy. She was admitted to the ICU with acute on chronic subdural hematoma and pneumonia after an unwitnessed fall. She is currently febrile, in atrial fibrillation, and non-responsive. She has a 24-hour EEG showing spikes that may represent subacute status epilepticus. She is receiving broad-spectrum antibiotics for pneumonia and aspiration, and has a pending C. difficile test.

Potential medical complications:

1. Subdural hematoma: The patient's subdural hematoma is at risk of worsening due to her low platelet count and the risk of spontaneous rebleeding.
2. Infection: The patient is at risk of developing a secondary infection, particularly given her pneumonia and aspiration.
3. Status epilepticus: The patient's EEG shows spikes that may represent subacute status epilepticus, which could lead to further neurological decline.
4. Renal failure: The patient's creatinine level is 1.1 mg/dL, indicating chronic kidney disease, which could worsen if not managed properly.
5. Pancytopenia: The patient's low white blood cell count, hemoglobin, and platelet count increase her risk of bleeding and infection.
6. Respiratory failure: The patient's pneumonia and aspiration put her at risk of respiratory failure, particularly if her oxygenation is not properly managed.
7. Cardiovascular instability: The patient's atrial fibrillation and hypertension increase her risk of cardiovascular instability, particularly if her blood pressure is not properly managed.
8. Gastrointestinal complications: The patient's diarrhea and potential C. difficile infection put her at risk of gastrointestinal complications, particularly if not properly managed.
9. Neurological decline: The patient's subdural hematoma, infection, and status epilepticus put her at risk of further neurological decline, particularly if not properly managed.

Assessment and plan:

The patient's condition is complex and requires close monitoring and management. The patient's subdural hematoma, infection, and status epilepticus need to be closely monitored and managed. The patient's pneumonia and aspiration require proper antibiotic management and oxygenation. The patient's pancytopenia and renal failure require close monitoring and management. The patient's cardiovascular instability requires proper blood pressure management. The patient's gastrointestinal complications require proper management of diarrhea and potential C. difficile infection. The patient's neurological decline requires close monitoring and management.

   # Oliguria
 Patient appears to be volume up on exam.  Was bolused
   yesterday.  Will give lasix for diuresis today.
   .
   # RUQ pain
 stable, unclear etiology, patient is post cholecystectomy
   so not gallbladder pain.  Could be rib fracture v. pleural pain v.
   colitis vs. pneumonia pain.
   - f/u abdominal ultrasound
 negative
   - CT abd and pelvis did not show pathology which could account for
   pain; consider possible obstructing stone as cause as it would not be
   well visualized on CT
   - no abx for now
   .
   # Subdural Hematoma: Neurosurgery following, no acute change from OSH
   imaging, no changes in repeat CT
   - original plan was to transfuse plt's with goal of >80, but pt has no
   evidence of bleeding on recent MRI head, will hold off for now, unless
   NS has different indication
   - INR 1.4, s/p Vit K treatment
   - continue dilantin at an appropriately corrected level; restarted
   lyrica as patient has NGT
   .
   # Afib with [**Name (NI) 1978**] - unclear precipitating factor, likely in setting of
   fever and new infection.  BPs stable, HRs to 140s.  Not changed with
   metoprolol; responsive to diltiazem
   - Titrating dilt po dose per pharmacy recs
   - echo done earlier in admission, no need to repeat at this time
   - no PE based on CTA
   - EKG without signs of ischemia
   .
   # Respiratory/PNA: Abx treatment included vanco and cefepime started
   [**3-29**].  Did get one dose of ceftriaxone.  Was started on levo for
   atypical coverage on [**3-29**] which was stopped [**4-2**].  Flagyl was started
   [**4-2**]. Culture data only positive for GPCs in sputum, no speciation
   done.  Is oxygentating well.
   - cont vancomycin, cefepime for 7 days (until [**4-5**]) , flagyl d/c
   - oxygen to maintain sats >92%
   - CXR stable
   .
   # Diarrhea: patient had an episode of diarrhea on [**2157-4-4**]
   - C. diff pending
   .
   # Falls/?Syncope: recent admit with extensive work-up attributing LE
   weakness and falls to cervical spondylosis and multilevel degenerative
   disease with myelopathy and neuropathy. Unclear if LOC with fall.
   - Cont. tele
   - MRA of neck done on last admit showing no flow limiting lesions
   - dilantin as above for seizure ppx
   - monitor resp status
   .
   # Myeloma: On pulse decadron as per heme-onc for tx of myeloma.
   - Next pulse due in 1 week.
   - will touch base with heme onc about next steroid dose
   .
   # Pancytopenia: [**3-7**] to myeloma.
   - Transfuse platelets with goal > 80K, on hold unless neuorsurg has
   good indication for transfusion; transfusing today
   - Transfuse hct < 21, rcv
d one unit [**2157-4-4**] in AM
   .
   # Renal Failure: At baseline from last admission. Unclear etiology to
   CKD, but may represent complication from myeloma.
   - Trend Cr
   - Cr stable at 1.2
   .
   # FEN: NGT TF at goal, replete lytes PRN
   .
   # Prophylaxis: pneumoboots (no SQ hep d/t SDH), PPI, pneumovax given at
   OSH
   .
   # Access: PIV x 2; will try to resite PICC line.
   .
   # Code: DNR/DNI per discussion with pt
s son on [**2157-4-4**]
   .
   # Communication: Patient, son is HCP
   .
   # Disposition: pending resp status improvement, PT c/s
   ICU Care

Summary:

The patient is an 82-year-old female with a history of multiple myeloma, frequent falls, and severe peripheral neuropathy who presented with an acute on chronic subdural hematoma and pneumonia after an unwitnessed fall. She was transferred to the MICU due to becoming non-responsive, febrile, and in atrial fibrillation. The patient is currently on mechanical ventilation, and her vital signs are stable. She has a history of pancytopenia, and her platelet count is currently 30,000/uL. She is receiving anticoagulation therapy and has been transfused with platelets. The patient has a subdural hematoma, which is being closely monitored by neurosurgery.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Seizure activity: The patient has a history of seizure activity, and her phenytoin level is still low. She may require further treatment to control her seizures.
2. Infection: The patient has a history of pneumonia and is currently receiving antibiotics. She may be at risk for further infection, particularly with her immunocompromised state.
3. Respiratory failure: The patient is on mechanical ventilation, and her respiratory status is being closely monitored. She may require further respiratory support or interventions.
4. Renal failure: The patient has a history of renal failure, and her creatinine level is currently stable at 1.2. She may require further monitoring and treatment for her renal function.
5. Bleeding: The patient has a subdural hematoma and is at risk for further bleeding. She may require further anticoagulation therapy or interventions to prevent bleeding.
6. Cardiovascular instability: The patient is in atrial fibrillation and has a history of cardiovascular disease. She may require further monitoring and treatment for her cardiovascular stability.
7. Neurological decline: The patient has a history of neurological decline, and her neurological status is being closely monitored. She may require further interventions or treatment to prevent further decline.

Recommendations:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's seizure activity and adjust her anticonvulsant therapy as needed.
2. Continue to monitor the patient's respiratory status and adjust her respiratory support as needed.
3. Continue to monitor the patient's renal function and adjust her treatment as needed.
4. Continue to monitor the patient's bleeding risk and adjust her anticoagulation therapy as needed.
5. Continue to monitor the patient's cardiovascular stability and adjust her treatment as needed.
6. Continue to monitor the patient's neurological status and adjust her treatment as needed.
7. Consider further interventions or treatment to prevent further neurological decline.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a critically ill individual in the Intensive Care Unit (ICU) with multiple comorbidities. Key findings include:

1. Fever: The patient's temperature is 101.7°C, which is concerning for sepsis. The patient has been pan-cultured and started on vancomycin and zosyn.
2. Electrolyte imbalance: The patient has an abnormal potassium level of 27 mEq/L, which may be contributing to the cardiac arrhythmia.
3. Respiratory compromise: The patient requires increased oxygen support, with a PaO2/FiO2 ratio of 389, indicating severe hypoxemia.
4. Cardiovascular instability: The patient has atrial fibrillation and is on furosemide (Lasix) for fluid management.
5. Renal dysfunction: The patient has acute renal failure, with a creatinine level of 1.5 mg/dL.
6. Coagulopathy: The patient has a low platelet count of 43 x 10^9/L.
7. Neurological impairment: The patient's mental status is altered, with no assessment of movement, tone, or responsiveness.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

1. Sepsis: The patient's fever, tachycardia, and tachypnea may indicate sepsis, which can lead to multi-organ dysfunction.
2. Cardiac arrhythmia: The patient's atrial fibrillation may worsen, leading to hemodynamic instability and cardiac arrest.
3. Respiratory failure: The patient's hypoxemia may worsen, requiring mechanical ventilation.
4. Renal failure: The patient's acute renal failure may progress, leading to electrolyte imbalance, fluid overload, and increased risk of mortality.
5. Bleeding: The patient's coagulopathy and platelet dysfunction may increase the risk of bleeding, particularly in the setting of invasive procedures.
6. Infections: The patient's immunocompromised state and presence of invasive lines and devices may increase the risk of infections, such as central line-associated bloodstream infections (CLABSIs) and ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP).

The patient's code status is DNR (do not resuscitate), indicating that the healthcare team has determined that aggressive resuscitation measures are not in the patient's best interest. The patient's disposition is unclear, but further management in the ICU is likely necessary to address the patient's complex medical issues.

Based on the patient's progress note, here is a summary of the patient's condition and potential medical complications:

**Current Condition:**

* The patient is an 82-year-old female with multiple myeloma, frequent recent falls, and severe peripheral neuropathy who is currently in the ICU due to an acute on chronic subdural hematoma and pneumonia.
* She has a fever of 101.7°F, pan-cultured, and is receiving treatment with vancomycin and zosyn.
* She has a history of pancytopenia, anemia, and thrombocytopenia due to myeloma.
* She has a subdural hematoma, which is being monitored, and has had a recent MRI showing acute on subacute embolic infarcts.
* She has a history of falls and is at risk for further falls due to her condition.

**Potential Medical Complications:**

* Seizure activity: The patient has had continuing epileptiform activity on EEG, and is being treated with Dilantin, Ativan, and Lyrica.
* Infection: The patient has a fever and is receiving treatment with antibiotics, but cultures have been negative so far.
* Oliguria: The patient has had a decrease in urine output and is at risk for further decline due to her underlying condition and medications.
* RUQ pain: The patient has stable RUQ pain, but the etiology is unclear and may be related to a possible obstructing stone.
* Subdural hematoma: The patient's subdural hematoma is being monitored, and repeat imaging may be necessary.
* Afib with unknown precipitating factor: The patient's atrial fibrillation is being treated with diltiazem, but the underlying cause is unclear.
* Respiratory failure: The patient has pneumonia and is receiving oxygen therapy, but is at risk for further decline due to her underlying condition.
* Diarrhea: The patient has had an episode of diarrhea and is at risk for further episodes due to her underlying condition.
* Falls: The patient is at risk for further falls due to her condition and medications.

**Assessment and Plan:**

* The patient's condition is being closely monitored, and further treatment will depend on the results of ongoing testing and imaging.
* The patient will continue to receive treatment for her pneumonia, and antibiotics will be continued as necessary.
* The patient's subdural hematoma will be monitored, and repeat imaging may be necessary.
* The patient's atrial fibrillation will be continued to be treated with diltiazem.
* The patient's pancytopenia will be monitored, and transfusions will be given as necessary.
* The patient's renal function will be closely monitored, and further treatment will depend on the results of ongoing testing.

**Recommendations:**

* The patient should continue to receive close monitoring and treatment for her underlying conditions.
* Further testing and imaging should be done as necessary to determine the cause of her symptoms and to guide treatment.
* The patient's family should be involved in the decision-making process and should be educated on the patient's condition and treatment plan.
* The patient's code status should be respected, and further treatment should be focused on comfort and symptom management.

Based on the patient's progress note, here is a summary of their current status:

The patient is a 24-hour-old ICU admission with a history of blood loss, bleeding, and abdominal pain. They have been transfused with 2 6-packs of platelets, and their EEG shows continuing epileptiform activity, but improved. The patient has a fever of 101.7°F, which was pan-cultured and started on vancomycin and zosyn. They have a positive urine analysis (bacteria, yeast, and LE) and a Foley catheter was changed.

The patient's vital signs are:

* Temperature: 101.7°F
* Heart rate: 99 bpm (normal range: 92-123 bpm)
* Blood pressure: 124/56 mmHg (normal range: 105-152/65-98 mmHg)
* Respiratory rate: 29 breaths per minute (normal range: 26-40 breaths per minute)
* SpO2: 97% (normal range: 95-100%)

The patient's physical examination is notable for:

* General appearance: Not well-nourished, no acute distress, thin
* Eyes: PERRL (pupils equal and reactive to light)
* Head, ears, nose, throat: Normocephalic, left eye ecchymosis resolving
* Neck: JVP (jugular venous pressure) elevated
* Cardiovascular: Normal PMI (point of maximal impulse), normal S1 and S2 heart sounds
* Respiratory: Symmetric lung expansion, wheezes and crackles in both lungs
* Abdominal: Soft, non-tender, bowel sounds present
* Extremities: Right and left radial pulses absent
* Skin: Warm
* Neurologic: Responds to noxious stimuli, oriented to nothing, non-purposeful movement, tone not assessed

The patient's laboratory results are:

* Hemoglobin: 8.1 g/dL
* Platelet count: 105 K/uL
* WBC count: 7.4 K/uL
* Creatinine: 1.1 mg/dL
* Blood urea nitrogen (BUN): 27 mg/dL
* Electrolytes: Na 134 mmol/L, K 4.5 mmol/L, Cl 106 mmol/L, HCO3 24.0 mmol/L
* Liver function tests (LFTs): ALT 57 IU/L, AST 73 IU/L, Alk Phos 74 IU/L, T Bili 0.6 mg/dL
* Renal function tests: BUN 27 mg/dL, Cr 1.1 mg/dL

The patient's diagnosis is:

* Anemia, acute, secondary to blood loss (hemorrhage, bleeding)
* Abdominal pain (including abdominal tenderness)
* Fever (hypothermia, pyrexia, not fever of unknown origin)
* Altered mental status (not delirium)
* Atrial fibrillation (AFIB)
* Renal failure, acute (acute renal failure, ARF)
* Rash

The patient's plan includes:

* Continued ICU care
* Nutrition: Nutren Pulmonary (full) at 40 mL/hour
* Glycemic control
* Lines: 20-gauge line
* Prophylaxis: DVT (deep vein thrombosis), stress ulcer, VAP (ventilator-associated pneumonia)
* Code status: DNR (do not resuscitate)
* Disposition: ICU

   Assessment and Plan
   82 y/o F w/ multiple myeloma, frequent recent falls in setting of
   severe peripheral neuropathy who now p/w acute on chronic subdural
   hematoma and pneumonia after an unwitnessed fall.  Transferred back to
   MICU after becoming non responsive, febrile and in afib with [**Telephone/Fax (3) 1978**].
   .
   # Encephalopathy
 Likely secondary to seizure activity.  CT of head
   negative for change in SDH and patient moving all 4 extremities. LENIs
   and CTA neg for clots
   - f/u pan cultures of blood, urine, stool
 so far negative
   - f/u LP cultures
 Neg prelim, neg Crypto
   - EEG
 f/u final read
   - Neuro
 start Ativan on top of Dilantin and Lyrica; dilantin level
   still low, will f/u with neuron; may take patient to Neuro step-down
   .
   # Fever
 Following fever curve, is immunocompromised secondary to
   pulse steroids for MM.  Finished treatment for HAP and aspiration
   pneumonia with broad spectrum vanco, cefepime ([**4-5**]).  Not covering
   ESBLs.  Also not covering fungal infections.
   - f/u cultures
 so far negative
   - remains hemodynamically stable
   .
   # Oliguria
 Patient appears to be volume up on exam.  Was bolused
   yesterday.  Will give lasix for diuresis today.
   .
   # RUQ pain
 stable, unclear etiology, patient is post cholecystectomy
   so not gallbladder pain.  Could be rib fracture v. pleural pain v.
   colitis vs. pneumonia pain.
   - f/u abdominal ultrasound
 negative
   - CT abd and pelvis did not show pathology which could account for
   pain; consider possible obstructing stone as cause as it would not be
   well visualized on CT
   - no abx for now
   .
   # Subdural Hematoma: Neurosurgery following, no acute change from OSH
   imaging, no changes in repeat CT
   - original plan was to transfuse plt's with goal of >80, but pt has no
   evidence of bleeding on recent MRI head, will hold off for now, unless
   NS has different indication
   - INR 1.4, s/p Vit K treatment
   - continue dilantin at an appropriately corrected level; restarted
   lyrica as patient has NGT
   .
   # Afib with [**Name (NI) 1978**] - unclear precipitating factor, likely in setting of
   fever and new infection.  BPs stable, HRs to 140s.  Not changed with
   metoprolol; responsive to diltiazem
   - Titrating dilt po dose per pharmacy recs
   - echo done earlier in admission, no need to repeat at this time
   - no PE based on CTA
   - EKG without signs of ischemia
   .
   # Respiratory/PNA: Abx treatment included vanco and cefepime started
   [**3-29**].  Did get one dose of ceftriaxone.  Was started on levo for
   atypical coverage on [**3-29**] which was stopped [**4-2**].  Flagyl was started
   [**4-2**]. Culture data only positive for GPCs in sputum, no speciation
   done.  Is oxygentating well.
   - cont vancomycin, cefepime for 7 days (until [**4-5**]) , flagyl d/c
   - oxygen to maintain sats >92%
   - CXR stable
   .
   # Diarrhea: patient had an episode of diarrhea on [**2157-4-4**]
   - C. diff pending
   .
   # Falls/?Syncope: recent admit with extensive work-up attributing LE
   weakness and falls to cervical spondylosis and multilevel degenerative
   disease with myelopathy and neuropathy. Unclear if LOC with fall.
   - Cont. tele
   - MRA of neck done on last admit showing no flow limiting lesions
   - dilantin as above for seizure ppx
   - monitor resp status
   .
   # Myeloma: On pulse decadron as per heme-onc for tx of myeloma.
   - Next pulse due in 1 week.
   - will touch base with heme onc about next steroid dose
   .
   # Pancytopenia: [**3-7**] to myeloma.
   - Transfuse platelets with goal > 80K, on hold unless neuorsurg has
   good indication for transfusion; transfused 1U [**4-6**]
   - Transfuse hct < 21, rcv
d one unit [**2157-4-4**] in AM
   .
   # Renal Failure: At baseline from last admission. Unclear etiology to
   CKD, but may represent complication from myeloma.
   - Trend Cr
   - Cr stable at 1.2
   .
   # FEN: NGT TF at goal, replete lytes PRN
   .
   # Prophylaxis: pneumoboots (no SQ hep d/t SDH), PPI, pneumovax given at
   OSH
   .
   # Access: PIV x 2; will try to resite PICC line.
   .
   # Code: DNR/DNI per discussion with pt
s son on [**2157-4-4**]
   .
   # Communication: Patient, son is HCP
   .
   # Disposition: pending resp status improvement, PT c/s

   - f/u pan cultures of blood, urine, stool
 so far negative
   - f/u LP cultures
 Neg prelim, neg Crypto
   - EEG
 f/u final read
   - Neuro
 start Ativan on top of Dilantin and Lyrica; dilantin level
   still low, will f/u with neuron; may take patient to Neuro step-down
   .
   # Fever
 Following fever curve, is immunocompromised secondary to
   pulse steroids for MM.  Finished treatment for HAP and aspiration
   pneumonia with broad spectrum vanco, cefepime ([**4-5**]).  Not covering
   ESBLs.  Also not covering fungal infections.
   - f/u cultures
 so far negative
   - remains hemodynamically stable
   .
   # Oliguria
 Patient appears to be volume up on exam.  Was bolused
   yesterday.  Will give lasix for diuresis today.
   .
   # RUQ pain
 stable, unclear etiology, patient is post cholecystectomy
   so not gallbladder pain.  Could be rib fracture v. pleural pain v.
   colitis vs. pneumonia pain.
   - f/u abdominal ultrasound
 negative
   - CT abd and pelvis did not show pathology which could account for
   pain; consider possible obstructing stone as cause as it would not be
   well visualized on CT
   - no abx for now
   .
   # Subdural Hematoma: Neurosurgery following, no acute change from OSH
   imaging, no changes in repeat CT
   - original plan was to transfuse plt's with goal of >80, but pt has no
   evidence of bleeding on recent MRI head, will hold off for now, unless
   NS has different indication
   - INR 1.4, s/p Vit K treatment
   - continue dilantin at an appropriately corrected level; restarted
   lyrica as patient has NGT
   .
   # Afib with [**Name (NI) 1978**] - unclear precipitating factor, likely in setting of
   fever and new infection.  BPs stable, HRs to 140s.  Not changed with
   metoprolol; responsive to diltiazem
   - Titrating dilt po dose per pharmacy recs
   - echo done earlier in admission, no need to repeat at this time
   - no PE based on CTA
   - EKG without signs of ischemia
   .
   # Respiratory/PNA: Abx treatment included vanco and cefepime started
   [**3-29**].  Did get one dose of ceftriaxone.  Was started on levo for
   atypical coverage on [**3-29**] which was stopped [**4-2**].  Flagyl was started
   [**4-2**]. Culture data only positive for GPCs in sputum, no speciation
   done.  Is oxygentating well.
   - cont vancomycin, cefepime for 7 days (until [**4-5**]) , flagyl d/c
   - oxygen to maintain sats >92%
   - CXR stable
   .
   # Diarrhea: patient had an episode of diarrhea on [**2157-4-4**]
   - C. diff pending
   .
   # Falls/?Syncope: recent admit with extensive work-up attributing LE
   weakness and falls to cervical spondylosis and multilevel degenerative
   disease with myelopathy and neuropathy. Unclear if LOC with fall.
   - Cont. tele
   - MRA of neck done on last admit showing no flow limiting lesions
   - dilantin as above for seizure ppx
   - monitor resp status
   .
   # Myeloma: On pulse decadron as per heme-onc for tx of myeloma.
   - Next pulse due in 1 week.
   - will touch base with heme onc about next steroid dose
   .
   # Pancytopenia: [**3-7**] to myeloma.
   - Transfuse platelets with goal > 80K, on hold unless neuorsurg has
   good indication for transfusion; transfused 1U [**4-6**]
   - Transfuse hct < 21, rcv
d one unit [**2157-4-4**] in AM
   .
   # Renal Failure: At baseline from last admission. Unclear etiology to
   CKD, but may represent complication from myeloma.
   - Trend Cr
   - Cr stable at 1.2
   .
   # FEN: NGT TF at goal, replete lytes PRN
   .
   # Prophylaxis: pneumoboots (no SQ hep d/t SDH), PPI, pneumovax given at
   OSH
   .
   # Access: PIV x 2; will try to resite PICC line.
   .
   # Code: DNR/DNI per discussion with pt
s son on [**2157-4-4**]
   .
   # Communication: Patient, son is HCP
   .
   # Disposition: pending resp status improvement, PT c/s
   ICU Care
